column1: LASIK is eye surgery that permanently changes the shape of the cornea (the clear covering on the front of the eye).
This allows images to be focused on the retina.
This gives the cornea a new shape so that light rays are focused clearly on the retina.
LASIK causes the cornea to be thinner.
LASIK is an outpatient surgical procedure.
A hinge on the flap prevents it from being completely separated from the cornea.
LASIK is most often done on people who use glasses or contact lenses because of nearsightedness (myopia).
- You should be at least 18 years old (21 in some cases, depending on the laser used), because vision may continue to change in people younger than 18.
Using LASIK to correct a very nearsighted eye may prevent amblyopia (lazy eye).
- You should not have this procedure if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, because these conditions can affect eye measurements.
Nearsightedness may continue to increase in some patients until their mid to late 20s.
LASIK may not be recommended for patients with diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, glaucoma, herpes infections of the eye, or cataracts.

Risks may include: - Corneal infection - Corneal scarring or permanent problems with the cornea's shape, making it impossible to wear contact lenses - Decrease in contrast sensitivity -- even with 20/20 vision, objects may appear fuzzy or gray - Dry eyes - Glare or haloes - Light sensitivity - Night driving problems - Patches of red or pink in the white of the eye (usually temporary) - Reduced vision or permanent vision loss - Scratchiness
A complete eye exam will be done before surgery to make sure your eyes are healthy.
Following the surgery: - You may have burning, itching, or a feeling that something is in the eye.
Most people's vision will stabilize in a few days after surgery, but for some people it may take up to 3 - 6 months.
Although a second surgery may improve distance vision, it may not relieve other symptoms, such as glare, haloes, or problems with night driving.
